user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_suspend_connection:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_suspend_connection (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = connection->daemon;

#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (daemon->tid) );
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Cannot suspend connections without " \
                  "enabling MHD_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME!\n"));
#ifdef UPGRADE_SUPPORT
  if (NULL != connection->urh)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Error: connection scheduled for \"upgrade\" cannot " \
                 "be suspended.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    return;
  }
#endif /* UPGRADE_SUPPORT */
  internal_suspend_connection_ (connection);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined the entire MHD_suspend_connection function provided. There are no calls to memcmp in this code, nor are there any comparisons of null-terminated strings using memcmp. The function only performs: flag/bitwise checks (daemon->options & ...), pointer checks (NULL != connection->urh), logging/panic calls with string literals, and calls to other functions/macros (MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_, MHD_PANIC, MHD_DLOG, internal_suspend_connection_). None of these lines in the shown fragment use memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. 

Note: If you want to be sure there is no violation elsewhere, the bodies/definitions of the called macros/functions (e.g., MHD_DLOG, MHD_PANIC, internal_suspend_connection_, or any macros expanded here) should be inspected, but they are not part of the provided code. Based solely on the provided function body, there are no suspicious fragments for Rule 21.14.
